Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Rheometer to Expand InterdisciplinaryMaterials Science Research with Undergraduate Researchers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award for a rheometer is expected to strengthen ongoing research at James Madison University focusing on the characterization and applications of soft materials through detailed rheological measurements. The rheometer can be configured to provide temperature control, visualization, and extensional, interfacial, concentric cylinder, and large particle rheometry. The instrument will directly lead to the training of undergraduate research assistants and will serve as an interdisciplinary tool in a variety of research projects focusing on the interplay of physical, chemical, and rheological properties of soft materials. The rheometer will serve as a shared resource at JMU's Center for Materials Science, which is composed of twenty faculty affiliates from six disciplines actively engaged in materials research. The four co-PIs will specifically conduct rheological examinations on novel self-assembled colloidal materials, flow dynamics of emulsions and foams, characterization of polymer nanocomposites, and jamming behavior of particulate suspensions.

Meaningful undergraduate research opportunities and active faculty mentoring are hallmarks of the educational philosophy at James Madison University. Fundamental and applied research will be conducted with undergraduates as primary participants. While largely a research tool, the rheometer will also be used as the basis of a laboratory experiment for an upper-level course on materials characterization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Major Research Instrumentation Award (1229383) enabled the acquisition of an Anton-Paar MCR-302 Rheometer, strengthening ongoing research in materials science at James Madison University (JMU). The three-year grant can be divided into three stages of approximately one year each:  acquisition/installment, training from the manufacturer, and initial use. Upon completion the award period, we now have a high quality research instrument with broad functionality and a critical mass of trained users. In addition, the instrument will receive ongoing support from an instrument technician through the JMU Center for Materials Science (CMS). The supported research, focusing on the characterization and applications of soft materials through detailed rheological measurements, has thus far involved eight undergraduate research students in work leading to multiple conference presentations and two articles in preparation. Its lasting impact is that the rheometer will serve as a tool for a wide variety of future investigations.

The intellectual merits of the project are through access to this new characterization technique that will benefit multiple research groups on campus. The rheometer can be configured to provide temperature control, visualization, and extensional, interfacial, concentric cylinder, and large particle rheometry. The rheometer will serve as a shared resource at JMU's Center for Materials Science, which is composed of twenty faculty affiliates from six disciplines actively engaged in materials research. The four co-investigators specifically conduct rheological examinations on novel self-assembled colloidal materials, flow dynamics of emulsions and foams, characterization of polymer nanocomposites, and jamming behavior of particulate suspensions. As a shared CMS facility however, it is accessible to all JMU faculty members.

Broader impacts occur largely through training of undergraduate science students. As a Primarily Undergraduate Institution, undergraduate students actively receive training on the instrument and gain valuable skills for future graduate study or employment. Meaningful undergraduate research opportunities and active faculty mentoring are hallmarks of the educational philosophy at James Madison University. Fundamental and applied research will be conducted with undergraduates as primary participants. In addition, a rheology experiment is being developed for a course MATS 381: Materials Characterization Lab, which is typically taken by 10-15 students each year pursuing minors in materials science. Those students completing the minor and/or involved in associated research groups are particularly likely to be impacted. The majority of these students intend on pursuing advanced studies in their fields and/or technical careers in science and engineering. 

After obtaining the instrument in year 1 and receiving training from the manufacturer in year 2, research labs began using the rheometer extensively in year 3. Initial data from three groups is highlighted in the attached images. In these, we show the pulling force on an aqueous foam versus distance (Figure 1), side images of the foam under experimental conditions (Figure 2), viscosity versus oscillation frequency for a polymer nanocomposite compared to pure polymer (Figure 3), and the torque or shear strength of a hydrophobic granular material versus time (Figure 4). These sample data represent the variety of measurements made thus far and indicate the wide array of rheological research that will be conducted in the future.
